title: Flávio Conceição
text:
Flávio da Conceição (born 12 June 1974) is a Brazilian former professional <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who played as a <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>.
Conceição enjoyed a successful career in Spain, where he played for two clubs—including <a href="Real%20Madrid%20C.F.">Real Madrid</a> with whom he won six major titles—and also represented <a href="Brazil%20national%20football%20team">Brazil</a> on more than 40 occasions.
Club career.
Born in <a href="Santa%20Maria%20da%20Serra">Santa Maria da Serra</a>, <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%20%28state%29">São Paulo</a>, Conceição began his career with <a href="Rio%20Branco%20Esporte%20Clube">Rio Branco</a> in 1992. He then joined <a href="Sociedade%20Esportiva%20Palmeiras">Palmeiras</a> a year later, and racked up over 100 first-team appearances during his spell. This caught the attention of Spanish club <a href="Deportivo%20de%20La%20Coru%C3%B1a">Deportivo de La Coruña</a>, who paid <a href="Euro">€</a>5.2 million for him after the <a href="1996%20Summer%20Olympics">1996 Summer Olympics</a>.
Playing alongside compatriot <a href="Mauro%20Silva">Mauro Silva</a> in central midfield, Conceição gradually developed into a key force in the <a href="Galicia%20%28Spain%29">Galicians</a>' rise in <a href="Football%20in%20Spain">Spanish football</a>, as he scored four goals in 27 games in the team's <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20La%20Liga">1999–2000 league conquest</a>. This led to a 2000 move to fellow <a href="La%20Liga">La Liga</a> side <a href="Real%20Madrid%20C.F.">Real Madrid</a>, worth €26 million.
Although he appeared sparingly, Conceição did win two league titles and the <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">2001–02 edition</a> of the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> – in that competition, he set up <a href="Steve%20McManaman">Steve McManaman</a> for the closing 2–0 semi-final win against <a href="FC%20Barcelona">FC Barcelona</a> at the <a href="Camp%20Nou">Camp Nou</a>. He spent the <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20Bundesliga">2003–04 campaign</a> on loan to <a href="Borussia%20Dortmund">Borussia Dortmund</a>, where he was also irregularly played.
In the summer of 2004, Conceição moved to Turkey's <a href="Galatasaray%20S.K.%20%28football%29">Galatasaray</a>. In <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20S%C3%BCper%20Lig">his first and only season</a> he won the <a href="Turkish%20Cup">Turkish Cup</a> but failed to make the Champions League, thus activating a clause in his contract which allowed him to leave, and he signed for <a href="Panathinaikos%20F.C.">Panathinaikos</a> of Greece.
Afflicted with injuries and loss of form, Conceição was released and retired at the age of 32.
International career.
Conceição earned 45 <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">caps</a> for <a href="Brazil%20national%20football%20team">Brazil</a> and scored four goals, and was part of the nation's <a href="1997%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">1997</a> and <a href="1999%20Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">1999</a> <a href="Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica">Copa América</a>-winning sides. He was also picked for two <a href="FIFA%20Confederations%20Cup">FIFA Confederations Cup</a> tournaments, making four appearances in the <a href="1997%20FIFA%20Confederations%20Cup">1997 edition</a> for the eventual champions.
In addition, Conceição <a href="Football%20at%20the%201996%20Summer%20Olympics">won a bronze medal</a> at the 1996 Olympics in <a href="Atlanta">Atlanta</a>, but was never summoned for any <a href="FIFA%20World%20Cup">FIFA World Cup</a>.
